32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mtchem.2023.101540" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mtchem.2023.101540</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S2468519423001672&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0015" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The presence of NaCl during synthesis promotes PBA with high Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;content.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Simple stirring with PEDOT-PSS dispersion produces PBA coated with PEDOT-PSS.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">PBA undergoes phase transition from rhombohedral-like to cubic after coating process.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">The as-prepared coated PBA delivers excellent electrochemical performance due to the improved electronic conduction.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010"><span><span><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are a promising alternative to complement costly lithium-ion batteries for grid-scale stationary energy storage systems. However, finding a suitable <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> has been a challenging process mainly due to the large radius of sodium-ion that hinders the process of intercalation. In our previous work, we have successfully synthesized Prussian blue analogue (PBA) via simple single iron source precipitation and low thermal method. However, it suffered poor </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>. In this work, the as-prepared PBA (high purity, low vacancy (∼2%), and high sodium-ion content) was then coated with various concentrations of conductive polymer poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/polystyrene" title="Learn more about polystyrene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polystyrene</a> sulfonate (PEDOT-PSS) via simple stirring method to aid the electron route. The coated PBA (PB–P5) demonstrates two-fold enhanced conductivity of 2.04&nbsp;×&nbsp;10</span><sup>−5</sup>&nbsp;S&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> at 30&nbsp;°C and 1.18&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−4</sup>&nbsp;S&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span><span> at 100&nbsp;°C. <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> peaks of coated PBAs show a slight shifting to higher diffraction angle, indicating the changes from rhombohedral-like to cubic structure. The battery capacity retention has also improved from 73.9% (PB–P0) to 82.87% (PB–P5), on account of having PEDOT-PSS to slow down the side reaction between cathode and electrolyte and eventually improve the cycling stability. Additionally, PB-P5 displays the lowest potential separation in </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) and small charge transfer resistance, </span><em>R</em><sub><em>ct</em></sub><span> value, in which indicating a better <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transfer</a> and enhanced overall conductivity.</span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2468519423001556"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2468519423001660"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Stationary energy storage system</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Precipitation</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Conductive polymer</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Conductivity</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span>For centuries, the main energy sources that come from the burning of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuels from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuels</a><span> have put up a huge <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/greenhouse-gas-emission" title="Learn more about greenhouse gas emission from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">greenhouse gas emission</a> across countries and are ultimately the largest driver of climate change [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span>]. As the energy usage is nowhere to tone down over the years, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/renewable-energy" title="Learn more about renewable energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy</a> development has emerged to offset world energy supply and demand. However, the main challenge arises as this kind of intermittent energy fluctuates over multiple time horizons and causes it hard to be effectively utilized. The idea to produce an energy storage system (ESS) with renewable energy source, forming a grid-scale energy storage system (GESS) helps to optimize the use of energy sources and gives a flexible flow in electricity demand [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>]. In the field of GESS, lithium-ion batteries are currently dominating the market as the main ESS [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>]. However, the concern over a rapid depletion of lithium reserves has called for an alternative energy storage for grid-scale application. Sodium-ion batteries (SIB) have raised the appeal as a potential candidate due to their similar mechanisms to lithium, but much cheaper, less toxic, and abundant in the earth [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>]. Still, enormous research works are required on finding a suitable cathode for SIB due to its drawbacks of having heavy and large radius of Na<sup>+</sup><span> resultant in high theoretical <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>In working on making SIB commercialized, a great effort has been made by researchers to synthesize a suitable <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> that can accommodate large Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ions without affecting <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> after long cycling and also attain a good battery performance in order to match with its lithium-ion battery counterpart. Various types of cathode materials, such as phosphate [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>], layered transition-metal oxides [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-polymer" title="Learn more about organic polymer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic polymer</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>], and Prussian blue analogue (PBA), had been extensively studied for the past decade in which PBA has become widely studied as cathode material due to its encouraging properties in a number of different battery types [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">With the generic formula of Na<sub><em>x</em></sub>M<sub>A</sub>[M<sub>B</sub>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>1−<em>y</em></sub>☐<sub><em>y</em></sub>·<em>n</em>H<sub>2</sub>O (where both M<sub>A</sub> and M<sub>B</sub> are the transition metals, <em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0&nbsp;−&nbsp;2, and ☐ is vacancies), PBA offer two different redox-active centers which correspond to the M<sub>A</sub><sup>2+/3+</sup> and M<sub>B</sub><sup>2+/3+</sup> couples in the structure that can give two-electron capacity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. Moreover, PBA also provide a variety of structural modifications such as substitutable transition metals in the structure that allows a multiple modification of PBA chemical composition [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a><span>]. The open framework and highly tunable properties of PBA also open the opportunities of possible intercalation by different ions including <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/alkali-metal" title="Learn more about alkali metals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">alkali metals</a> and divalent ions [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a><span>]. Additionally, the vacancies in the structure can be modified by using different synthesis routes, thus giving opportunities for researchers to explore strategies to improve the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of battery.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">One of the main challenges of introducing PBA for practical use is the forming of vacancies and defects in framework [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. The original route of PBA synthesis that consists of Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup> naturally implies 25% vacancy of [Fe<sup>Ⅱ</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4-</sup>, resulting from the neutral charge of mixed-valence compound [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. These large number of vacancies and defects can give various adverse effects, such as allowing more water molecules to reside in the empty space of the structure, thereby hindering the transportation of Na into the lattice [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. The defects also decrease the number of active Fe<sup>2+/3+</sup><span><span> redox sites which means it could reduce the capacity and capability of the battery due to the unstable structure occupied by vacancies. Over the past years, many synthesis methods have been explored to control the nucleation of PBA crystals thus promoting the low <a href="/topics/materials-science/defect-structure" title="Learn more about defect structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">defect structure</a>. A high-quality PBA crystal has been reported by You et&nbsp;al. through single iron source precursor to slow down the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/crystallization" title="Learn more about crystallization process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallization process</a>, promoting high specific capacity close to the theoretical value (170&nbsp;mAhg</span><sup>−1</sup>) and high cycling stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. A different route of synthesis with the aid of chelating agents was also attempted by number of researchers to suppress the vacancy formation. A facile citrate-assisted controlled crystallization method has purposed by Wu et&nbsp;al. in order to synthesize low defect PBA structure that demonstrated high specific capacity of 150&nbsp;mAhg<sup>−1</sup> and impressive cycle stability with ∼90% capacity retention over 200 cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a><span>]. Recently, a new approach of introducing carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) as chelating agents was conducted by Jiang et&nbsp;al. which promoted an optimal binding energy between CMC and <a href="/topics/materials-science/iron-ion" title="Learn more about Fe ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fe ions</a>, thus exhibiting a high stability PBA structure with capacity retention of 97.4% over 3000 cycles [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span>]. The morphologically controlled PBA by acid tailoring assisted by PVP as <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-active-agent" title="Learn more about surfactant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surfactant</a> also conducted by Liu et&nbsp;al. in which exhibited 107&nbsp;mAhg</span><sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>-1</sup> and high capacity of 70&nbsp;mAhg<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>-1</sup> in full cell system (using hard carbon anode) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. An improved structural stability using PVP was also demonstrated by Huang et&nbsp;al. in which the electrode exhibited capacity retention of 79% after 500 cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span><span>In addition to struggling with the vacancies and defects of the structure, PBA also suffer with poor <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> that hinder the electron pathway thus limiting their application as energy storage. A number of studies have been reported for the work of introducing composite materials to PBA in order to improve the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/conduction-electron" title="Learn more about electron conduction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron conduction</a> of materials and thus increase the electrochemical performance of the cell. Traditionally, carbon coating was the first choice of method to resolve the issue regarding the low conductivity of electrode materials. However, the conflict arises as the high temperature of carbon pyrolysis method (&gt;500&nbsp;°C) can cause the decomposition of PBAs [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a><span>]. Another coating method has been done by using a low-temperature setting to avoid the destruction of PBA structure, such as implementing a conductive polymer layer of the surface to enhance the electrical pathway of the PBA cathodes. <a href="/topics/materials-science/polyaniline" title="Learn more about Polyaniline from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Polyaniline</a> (PANI) coating on PBA has been reported by Zhang et&nbsp;al. using the polymerization reaction of aniline and then forming a core–shell structure in which successfully delivered the capacity of 108.3&nbsp;mAhg</span><sup>−1</sup> at 100&nbsp;mAg<sup>−1</sup> and capacity retention of 93.4% after 500 cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. The same PANI coated-PBA with a different approach of coating method was reported by other researchers. Instead of direct polymerization on PBA, Luo et&nbsp;al. employed the uniform PANI coating by adding aniline into the electrolyte and allowing the polymerization under the electrochemical setting [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. This kind of method somehow showed a better capacity retention compared to the uncoated one with ∼22.6% and exhibited 113.3&nbsp;mAhg<sup>−1</sup> capacity at 20&nbsp;C. A facile <em>in situ</em> polymerization method of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) coating also performed by Wang et&nbsp;al. to boost electronic conduction and suppress the side reactions, resulted in an excellent capacity with 147.9&nbsp;mAhg<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C and retained 78.2% capacity at 10&nbsp;C after 1000 cycles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a><span><span>]. The interested conductive <a href="/topics/materials-science/polymer-coating" title="Learn more about polymer coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polymer coating</a> of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/polystyrene" title="Learn more about polystyrene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polystyrene</a> sulfonate (PEDOT-PSS) was purposed by Kim et&nbsp;al. due to its superior flexibility and electrical conductivity compared to the other conductive polymers in which reported a high reversible capacity of 130.9&nbsp;mAhg</span><sup>−1</sup> and stable cycle performance with ∼96% capacity retention up to 100 cycles at 50&nbsp;mAg<sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">In this work, we proposed the PEDOT-PSS coating method on the as-prepared PBA to improve its conductivity and thus enhance the battery performance. However, too much coating of PEDOT-PSS must be avoided because it is electrochemically inactive toward Na<sup>+</sup>. Thus, there is a need to optimize the amount of PEDOT-PSS that can give the highest battery performance. In contrast with previous work reported in the literature [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>], we used a single-step synthesis route with the aid of PVP as surfactant to control the nucleation rate of PBA and produce high purity, low vacancy (∼2%), and high Na<sup>+</sup> content of PBA [Na<sub>1.6</sub>Fe[Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.98</sub>◻<sub>0.02</sub>]. We also performed an additional study on electrical properties of the coated PBA pellet at various temperatures (30–100&nbsp;°C) and SIB half-cells before and after cycling.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of PBA</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">All the chemicals were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The synthesis of PBA was done via low thermal and single iron source method. Initially, 35&nbsp;g of NaCl was dissolved in HCl solution to obtain 300&nbsp;ml of 2&nbsp;M NaCl–HCl solution. Then, 6.67&nbsp;g of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, M<sub>w</sub> ∼40,000) and 1.45&nbsp;g of Na<sub>4</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O were added into the solution and magnetically stirred for 2&nbsp;h at room temperature, turning the clear solution into a faint yellow. The solution was then heated in an electric oven at 80&nbsp;°C for 24&nbsp;h and then aged at room temperature for another 20&nbsp;h. At this step, the solution formed a dark blue precipitate at the bottom layer and almost clear supernatant at top. The precipitate then was collected by centrifugation and washed with H<sub>2</sub>O and ethanol. The precipitate then was dried in vacuum oven at 60&nbsp;°C overnight, and the obtained dark blue powder was assigned as PB-P0.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Coating with PEDOT-PSS</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">The as-prepared PBA was weighted 500&nbsp;mg and then completely dispersed in 20&nbsp;ml distilled water. Then, a various volume of PEDOT-PSS dispersion (PEDOT-PS 3.0–4.0% in H<sub>2</sub>O) (0.3, 0.5, and 1.0&nbsp;ml) was added into the PBA dispersion and magnetic stirred for 24&nbsp;h. Finally, the precipitate was collected again by centrifugation and dried in vacuum oven at 60&nbsp;°C overnight. The obtained powder was assigned as PB-P3, PB-P5, and PB-P10 according to the 0.3&nbsp;ml, 0.5&nbsp;ml, and 1.0&nbsp;ml amount of PEDOT-PSS used, respectively.</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Physical characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><span><span>The morphology of PBA samples was collected by <a href="/topics/materials-science/field-emission-scanning-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about field emission scanning electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">field emission scanning electron microscopy</a> (JEOL JEM-2100F) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (JEOL JSM-7600F). The element and structure analyses of PBA were conducted using energy dispersive X-ray analysis (JEOL JEM-2100F), micro-Raman spectra (Renishaw inVia), and X-ray </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a> analysis (Malvern Panalytical EMPYREAN) with Cu Kα radiation (wavelength, </span><em>λ</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Å, 2θ from 10° to 80°).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">To study the impedance, the samples were first pelletized into <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/disks-shapes" title="Learn more about disc shape from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disc shape</a> with 13&nbsp;mm in diameter and ∼ 0.2&nbsp;cm thickness. The pellet was pressed using hydraulic hand pump with 400&nbsp;bar. The impedance of pellet was characterized using HIOKI 3531 Z Hi-tester with frequency from 50&nbsp;Hz to 5&nbsp;MHz at temperature ranging from 30 to 100&nbsp;°C.</div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">The slurry of PBA cathodes was done by mixing and stirring poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), PBA active material, and carbon black in a ratio of 1:8:1 using N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) as solvent. The slurry then was coated uniformly on <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminum foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum foil</a> as a current collector and dried on the hot plate until NMP evaporated. Then, the coated foil was punch into circular shape with 12&nbsp;mm diameter and press rolled in between foils with hydraulic hand pump.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120"><span><span>The fabrication of half-cells was done inside the argon-filled glovebox where the moisture and oxygen are &lt;1&nbsp;ppm. <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about Sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium</a> metal was used as counter electrode with 14&nbsp;mm in diameter, and glass </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/microfiber" title="Learn more about microfiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microfiber</a> was used as separator with 16&nbsp;mm in diameter. The electrolyte used was 1.0&nbsp;M NaPF</span><sub>6</sub> in EC:PC&nbsp;=&nbsp;1:1, and the half-cells were assembled in the CR2032-type coin cell.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125"><span>The cells were then tested by galvanostatic charge–discharge measurements using multichannel battery testing workstation BTS (Neware Technology Inc., China) in the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V at various C-rates. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) was done using Metrohm Multi Autolab with voltage ranging from 2.0 to 4.0&nbsp;V at scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mVs</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) of fabricated PBA was conducted using the same instrument with the frequency ranging from 0.01&nbsp;Hz to 100&nbsp;kHz with amplitude voltage of 10&nbsp;mV.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;1</span></span></a><span> shows the FESEM and <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a><span> images of PBA coated with different concentrations of PEDOT-PSS. The FESEM image of PB-P0 in which the uncoated PB displays a single cubic structure with size ranging from 1 to 2&nbsp;μm and shows almost perfect shape with less obvious defects due to the aid of PVP as <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-active-agent" title="Learn more about surfactant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surfactant</a> during the synthesis process. The presence of sufficient surfactant temporarily stabilizes the preformed particles in solution and then helps them to aggregate in an ordered way [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. Morphological images of PB-P0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;1</span></span></a><span>a,e) show smooth surface of PBA structure suggesting that no impurities are presented or attached on the exterior of PBA. However, after the <a href="/topics/materials-science/coating-process" title="Learn more about coating process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating process</a> was done, all the facets of PBA structures seem to be covered and coarsened by coating material PEDOT-PSS as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;1</span></span></a>b–d. The HRTEM images of PBAs (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;1</span></span></a>e–h) reveal the various intensity of inhomogeneous PEDOT-PSS fragments on PBA surface, as PB-P10 shows much dense PEDOT-PSS fragments compared to other coated PBA. From both FESEM and HRTEM images, it can be speculated that the intensity of coated PEDOT-PSS increases with the concentration of PEDOT-PSS used during coating process.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr1.jpg" height="289" alt="Fig.&nbsp;1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (531KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (531KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig.&nbsp;1</span>. FESEM (top row) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> (bottom row) images of (a,e), PB-0, (b,f) PB-P3, (c,g) PB-P5 and (d,h) PB-P10.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0135"><span>X-ray diffraction analysis was performed on all PBA samples to investigate the <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice constant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice constant</a> and structural change before and after coating with PEDOT-PSS. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a><span>a shows the <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> pattern of PBAs and standard of the PBA crystal (JCPDS No. 52–1907) with face-centered cubic (FCC) with space group of </span><em>Fm-3m</em><span>. From the spectrum, it can be observed that all main peaks of PBAs are assignable to the standard, and no additional peak was observed suggesting no impurities are present. The spectra also show no peaks that correspond to PEDOT-PSS due to its <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> phase [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>]. The peaks detected for PB-P0 at 2<em>θ</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;17.3°, 24.4°, 34.7°, 38.9°, 42.8°, 49.8°, and 53.0° were assigned to crystal planes of (200), (220), (400), (420), (422), (440), and (600), respectively, and seem to form at lower diffraction angle compared to standard PBA due to the high concentration of NaCl used during synthesis process. The dissociation of NaCl in acidic solution increases Na<sup>+</sup> concentration, thus promotes the insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> into the unit cell. The large quantity of Na<sup>+</sup> insertion can cause the distortion of lattice plane of PBAs, thus forming a rhombohedral-like structure with the calculated lattice constant of 10.32&nbsp;Å rather than ideal cubic one (10.20&nbsp;Å) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>]. The change in lattice plane was observed after PBAs were coated with PEDOT-PSS in which the main peaks of each PBA sample shifted toward higher diffraction angles compared to PB-P0. The calculated lattice constant is 10.26&nbsp;Å for all coated samples, indicating the changes from rhombohedral-like to cubic structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. It can be depicted that such slight shifting is correlated to the reduction of Na content inside the PBA framework after coating as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;2</span></span></a>b [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. However, it was observed that no diffraction peaks for PEDOT-PSS, feasibly due to its low content making it hard to be detected.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr2.jpg" height="459" alt="Fig.&nbsp;2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (499KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (499KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig.&nbsp;2</span>. (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> profile and (b) schematic illustration of rhombohedral-like changes to cubic structure.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">The elemental composition of PBA samples was depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table&nbsp;S1</span></span></a> (EDX spectrum in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a><span>a and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a> elemental mapping in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;S1</span></span></a> for PB-P0) in which only display elements that contained in PBA and PEDOT-PSS without any detectable peaks for impurities. It was noted that the element sulfur in PEDOT-PSS is hard to be detected due to the small atomic ratio compared to other elements (chemical structure of typical PEDOT-PSS as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;S2</span></span></a> as reference). However, a small peak for sulfur (S 2p) was detected in XPS profile for PB-P5 as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;S3</span></span></a>c, indicating the presence of PEDOT-PSS on PBA. The carbon element shows an increasing trend in percentage along with the increasing of PEDOT-PSS concentration used during coating process.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr3.jpg" height="637" alt="Fig.&nbsp;3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (649KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (649KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2468519423001672-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig.&nbsp;3</span>. (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a><span> spectrum, (b) XPS spectrum (Fe) of PB-P0, and (c) <a href="/topics/materials-science/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> of PBA samples.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">To determine the precise composition of as-prepared PBA, XPS was conducted in which the ratio of Fe (II) and Fe (III) can be calculated. XPS spectrum (Fe) of PB-P0 as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a>b exhibits four main peaks at 708.7&nbsp;eV, 711.44&nbsp;eV, 721.36&nbsp;eV, and 724.24&nbsp;eV in which correspond to Fe (II) 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, Fe (III) 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, Fe (II) 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, and Fe (III) 2p<sub>1/2</sub><span>, respectively. The ratio of Fe (II):Fe (III) was calculated to be 0.98:1. By normalizing Fe (III) mole ratio to 1, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/stoichiometry" title="Learn more about stoichiometry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stoichiometry</a> of as-prepared PB-P0 can be calculated as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table&nbsp;S2</span></span></a> and giving the chemical formula of Na<sub>1.6</sub>Fe[Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.98</sub>◻<sub>0.02</sub>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;3</span></span></a><span>c demonstrates the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectrum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectrum</a> of all PBA samples that reveal similar intensity bands at shift 2145.4, 2119.6, and 2083.8&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−1</sup> in which all of them correspond to the C≡N bond stretching vibrations in Prussian blue [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. Two bands were detected at 1450.9&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> and 1522.2&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;(C=C stretching region) for coated PBAs (PB–P3, PB-P5, and PB-P10) that were assigned to symmetric and asymmetric stretching of C<sub>α</sub>C<sub>β</sub>, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>]. It was noticed that the intensity of those bands increases with the increasing concentration of PEDOT-PSS used, indicating the successful coating process on the PBA surface.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0155"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>a and b depicts the complex impedance plot of pelletized PBA samples at 30&nbsp;°C and 100&nbsp;°C. At low temperature, the plots exhibit a depressed semicircle that indicates the non-Debye behavior and a spike for all samples, attribute to the bulk conduction and double-layer capacitance, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. The intercept of semicircle at mid-frequency with real axis will give the value of bulk resistance, <em>R</em><sub><em>b</em></sub><span>, that can be used to calculate the <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-conductivity" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a> of the samples with the following equation [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]:<span class="display"><span id="ufd1" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>d</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>A</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="8.407ex" height="3.702ex" viewBox="0 -995.6 3619.7 1593.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.389ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C3"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(850,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1628,0)"><g transform="translate(397,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="1473" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(551,410)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-64"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-411)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(537,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(822,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-41"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">σ</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msub><mi is="true">A</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">σ</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi><mi is="true">b</mi></msub><mi is="true">A</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where <em>σ</em> is the conductivity of sample, <em>d</em> is the thickness of pellet, <em>R</em><sub><em>b</em></sub> is the bulk resistance, and <em>A</em> is the surface area of the pellet. The comparison plot in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a><span>a reveals that the diameter of semicircle getting smaller from PB-P0, PB-P3, PB-P5, and PB-P10 specified that the bulk resistance of the sample decreases with the increase of PEDOT-PSS concentration, thus enhancing in <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>. On the other hand, the appearance of two semicircles was observed at higher temperature of 100&nbsp;°C, in which the one at higher frequency attributes to the bulk resistance, </span><em>R</em><sub><em>b</em></sub>, and at lower frequency is for grain boundary resistance, <em>R</em><sub><em>gb</em></sub><span>. A similar trend was also observed at this temperature setting in which PB-P10 exhibits the smallest bulk resistance, followed by PB-P5, PB-P3, and PB-P0, respectively. The calculated <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ion-current" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a> and the relationship between conductivity and temperature for PBA pellets were depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table&nbsp;S3</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig.&nbsp;4</span></span></a>c, respectively. The conductivity value of PB-P0, PB-P3, PB-P5, and PB-P10 at 30&nbsp;°C are calculated as 9.58&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−6</sup>, 1.37&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−5</sup>, 2.04&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−5</sup>, and 4.38&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>−5</sup>, respectively, with a minimum enhancement of 43%. It can also be noted that the conductivity of pelletized PBAs increases linearly with the temperature setting, suggesting a thermally activated conduction behavior in PBA samples [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a><span>]. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/activation-energy" title="Learn more about activation energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation energy</a> of the samples can be calculated from the slope of the plot that obeys the Arrhenius rule:</span><span class="display"><span id="ufd2" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-4-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi><mn xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-115)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-41"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(243,-395)"><g
